questions.text: A 55-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with fever with chills, diarrhea and new onset cardiac murmur. Candida species are isolated from her blood culture and IV fluconazole is considered for treatment. Which of the following Candida species is least likely to respond to azole therapy?

A 32-year-old HIV-positive male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of worsening shortness of breath, dry cough, and fever. He reports significant weight loss over the past month and has a CD4 count of 150 cells/mm³. HRCT Thorax shows ground-glass opacities. A bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is performed, and a histological examination shows organisms with a characteristic appearance, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pneumocystis jirovecii

Morphology
  1. Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size
  2. Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size
  3. Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size

Risk factors
  • HIV: CD4 < 200
  • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Clinical features

transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dyspnoea
  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia

Diagnosis
  • GMS / Giemsa stain- mc used
  • Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains can demonstrate trophozoites - cyst wall is black with a methenamine silver stain.

Crushed Ping Pong ball (also called Helmet/Hat or Cup and Saucer appearance).

 

  • The β-d-glucan test has proven to be quite useful for rapid diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia with a high degree of sensitivity and specificity.

Treatment
  • The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
 
  • Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with facial swelling, nasal discharge, and fever. He has a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. On examination, there is necrosis of the nasal turbinates and blackish discharge. A CT scan of the sinuses reveals extensive necrosis. A tissue biopsy shows non-septate, wide-angle hyphae similar to the image given below. What is the most common causative organism of the above condition?
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

 

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

 

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

 

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
 
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
 
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

 

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

a.Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

b.Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

A 55-year-old male with a history of COPD presents to the emergency department with 1-week history of fever, cough, and worsening shortness of breath. Colonies exhibiting a yellow-green color and a velvety texture were isolated from the culture. He is immunocompromised due to long-term corticosteroid therapy. The attending physician wants to initiate antifungal therapy. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspergillosis

Type

Pathology

Features

1. ABPA (allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis)

Inhaled spores provoke hypersensitivity reaction:

  • Type 1: asthma
  • Type 3: extrinsic alveolitis
  • Combined type 1 and type 3
 

Chest X-ray showing: left-sided perihilar opacity (blue arrow) along with non-homogeneous infiltrates (transient pulmonary infiltrates indicated by red arrows) in all zones of both lung fields

2. Aspergilloma

Fungal ball grows within and is restricted to an existing lung cavity, for example, due to old tuberculosis infection or bronchiectasis.
 

CT of a simple aspergilloma of the right lung

3. Invasive aspergillosis

Fungus first causes pneumonia and later disseminates to involve other organs, for example, the brain, kidney or heart.

 

Patients who develop this disease are usually immunocompromised or debilitated due to prolonged treatment with antibiotics, steroids and cytotoxic drugs.
 

Invasive Aspergillus infection showing a nodule with a halo sign at the periphery (arrows).

4. Superficial

Superficial infections of the external ear ( otomycosis), the eye (mycotic keratitis) and the nasal sinuses.

  

Otomycosis of the External Canal (Wet newspaper appearance)

A. Mycotic keratitis B.Under cobalt blue filter after instillation of fluorescein dye.

Diagnosis

Culture

Colonies have a velvety to powdery surface and are characteristically coloured: A.fumigatus - dark green, A.niger - black, A.flavus - yellow-green, A.terreus - beige coloured colonies.

 

 

Aspergillus fumigatus

 

Aspergillus niger

 

Aspergillus flavus 

 

Aspergillus terreus

Histopathology

Stain used - Lactophenol cotton blue

It demonstrates septate hyphae and acute angled (<45°) / Dichotomous branching.

Others

Detection of galactomannan

Tissue sections: biopsy (stained with GMS/PAS)

Treatment

Medical

Drug of choice: Voriconazole (Option A)

2nd line drugs: Itraconazole (Option C), Posaconazole

Other drugs: Amphotericin B (Option B) / Liposomal amphotericin B

Surgical resection (Option D)

May be indicated for localized fungal infections, such as aspergillomas or when there are complications such as abscess formation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Cryptococcus are correct? i. It is a mould type of fungi ii. Polypeptide capsule provides significant protection against phagocytosis. iii. Exposure to bird droppings can increase the likelihood of infection. iv. Cryptococcus neoformans is the principle pathogenic species v. Cryptococcus gattii is associated with B, C serotypes.
questions.explanation:
Cryptococcus Spp.

Cryptococcus is a true yeast. (Statement i)

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis . (Statement ii)

Serotypes

A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans (Statement iv)

B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii (Statement v)

Virulence factors
  • Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread.
  • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.
  • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:
  • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.
  • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

Risk of infection

Immunocompromised States:

  • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

Geographic Location:

  • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

Environmental Exposure:

  • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans. (Statement iii)

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to her primary care physician with complaints of intense vaginal itching, a thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge, and irritation. Per vaginal examination reveals the following finding. The vaginal pH is found to be acidic (approximately 4.5). What is the most appropriate management for this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Vaginal candidiasis

Risk factors

  • Old age
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Corticosteroid use
  • Pregnancy
  • Immunocompromised states - HIV
  • Low neutrophil count

Presentation

Intense vaginal itching and irritation

Splash dysuria seen

Thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge

Treatment

Topical nystatin - DOC for uncomplicated cases

 

Oral fluconazole (Option B) used for more severe or recurrent infections that do not respond to standard treatment.

questions.explanation:
Laboratory diagnosis of Candida

Germ tube test
  • The germ tube test is a specific diagnostic test for Candida albicans.
  • Germ tube is also seen in Candida dubliniensis
  • Candida tropicalis- pseudo germ tube formation
 

Also known as Reynolds Braude Phenomenon

Candida + Human serum → Incubation → Big tube-like structure (Pseudohyphae).

Gram stain

Yeast-like organism - Has both buds and pseudohyphae.

SDA Culture media test

Colonies are creamy white, smooth and with a yeasty odor

Corn meal agar test

Forms chlamydospores on corn meal agar cultures at 20°C -identified by double wall configuration.

Chrom agar test

Colour differentiation test

Each type of organism is seen differently

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with white patches on the tongue and inner cheeks. On examination, the lesions can be scraped off, revealing a red, inflamed base. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Oral candidiasis

Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is an infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans, a type of yeast.

Presentation

Presence of white patches that can be scraped off, leaving behind a red inflamed base

Risk factors

  • Diabetes: Poorly controlled diabetes creates a favorable environment for Candida growth due to elevated blood sugar levels.
  • Neutropenia
  • Immunosuppression: HIV/AIDS, cancer, or immunosuppressive medications increase susceptibility.
  • Use of inhaled corticosteroids
  • Antibiotic Use: Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt normal oral flora, allowing Candida to overgrow.
  • Poor Oral Hygiene: Leads to an increase in fungal colonization.
  • Dry Mouth: Conditions that lead to reduced saliva production can promote candidiasis.

Treatment
  • Antifungal medications, such as nystatin or fluconazole, along with addressing any underlying risk factors.
  • C. krusei- Resistant to azoles

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the clinic with a persistent cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain for the past month. She is currently on immunosuppressive therapy for an autoimmune condition. A chest CT reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right upper lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical features of cryptococcosis

Respiratory system
  • Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection/pneumonitis - primary site of infection
  • Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress.
  • Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule
  • Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to involvement of other organs

Central Nervous System

Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision

It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection

Skin

Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D)

Other Organs

Liver, spleen, and bones may be involved in disseminated infections

questions.text: A 35-year-old male, known to be HIV positive, presents with fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. A lumbar puncture is performed to analyze his cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and following microscopic findings are observed. What stain has been used here to visualize the organism?
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis of Cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.
